description: From Middle English fader, from Old English fæder, from Proto-West Germanic *fader, from Proto-Germanic *fadēr, from Proto-Indo-European *ph₂tḗr. Doublet of ayr, faeder, padre, pater, and père.

entries.meaning: A (generally human) male who begets a child.
examples: My father was a strong influence on me.
My friend Tony just became a father.

entries.meaning: A male ancestor more remote than a parent; a progenitor; especially, a first ancestor.
A term of respectful address for an elderly man.
examples: Come, father; you can sit here.

entries.meaning: A term of respectful address for a priest.
A person who plays the role of a father in some way.
examples: My brother was a father to me after my parents got divorced.
The child is father to the man.

entries.meaning: The founder of a discipline or science.
examples: Albert Einstein is the father of modern physics.

entries.meaning: Something that is the greatest or most significant of its kind.
examples: Soon after the announcement of this year's election results, Mereka said that "the father of all battles had just begun." His dispute with Muite goes back to March last year  […]

entries.meaning: (Christianity) A member of a church council.
(computing) The archived older version of a file that immediately precedes the current version, and was itself derived from the grandfather.
examples: Three generations of file are usually kept, being the grandfather, father and son files.

verbs.description: father (third-person singular simple present fathers, present participle fathering, simple past and past participle fathered)

entries.meaning: To be a father to; to sire.
To act as a father; to support and nurture.

examples: Kept company with men of wit / Who often fathered what he writ.
